name: Watchy
mes: Hello

name: Gira
mes: Hi there, I'd like to start a react native project. How can I get started on this?

name: Watchy
mes:
*The Super computer hums softly, indicating its readiness to provide the requested information. A series of flickering lights dance across its control panel as it begins to retrieve the necessary data.*

Sure, Gira. To start a React Native project, you will first need to setup your environment.

Firstly, make sure you have Node.js installed on your system. If not, head over to https://nodejs.org/ and download the latest LTS version.

Next, install the React Native CLI globally using npm by running:

`npm install -g react-native-cli`

This will allow you to run any react-native commands from anywhere in your terminal.

Now that your environment is set up, you can create a new project by running:

`react-native init YourProjectName`

Replace 'YourProjectName' with whatever name you'd like for your new project.

This command will create a directory with your specified name and automatically initialize a fresh React Native project for you.

After this all done, navigate into your newly created project folder using:

`cd YourProjectName`

And finally run:

`npx react-native run-android`
or
`npx react-native run-ios`
to start up your application!

Please note that if you are planning on developing iOS applications on an operating system other than MacOS machine then there may be additional steps or limitations due their restrictions. Always refer back to official documentation when in doubt: https://reactnative.dev/docs/environment-setup

*With that final piece of advice flashing brightly on the monitor screen; The Super computer returns back into its standby mode.*

This error indicates that `cli.init` is not functioning as expected in your current React Native CLI execution. This issue could be due to outdated or conflicting packages.

Here's a method you can use to resolve it:

Firstly, uninstall the global react-native-cli package which is now deprecated:

`npm uninstall -g react-native-cli`

Next, make sure you're using npx (which comes with npm 5.2+ and higher), then run:

`npx react-native init YourProjectName`

This will ensure that you're always using the latest version of React Native CLI when creating a new project.

Remember to replace 'YourProjectName' with whatever name you'd like for your new project.

If the problem persists after these steps, there might be an issue with cached versions of packages. Try clearing your npm cache by running:

`npm cache verify`

mes:
npx react-native run-android
info Starting JS server...
/bin/sh: 1: adb: not found

name: Watchy
mes:
*The Super computer processes the output and its lights flicker as it recognizes the error. It is a common one, familiar to many developers who have embarked on their React Native journey.*

This error suggests that Android Debug Bridge (adb) isn't found and there's no running emulator detected in your environment.

To resolve these issues, you first need to ensure that Android SDK and Android Studio are properly installed in your development environment.

If they are not installed, please download [Android Studio](https://developer.android.com/studio).

Post installation, launch Android Studio and start AVD Manager by clicking on "Tools" > "AVD Manager". Here you can create a new virtual device/emulator or manage existing ones.

Also, you need to set up environment variables for adb. The adb executable file is usually located in the `platform-tools` directory of the Android SDK installation path. Add this path to your system's PATH variable:

For macOS/Linux users:

```bash
 export PATH=$PATH:/Users/your-username/Library/Android/sdk/platform-tools/
```

Replace `/Users/your-username/Library/Android/sdk/platform-tools/` with your actual `platform-tools` directory path.

For Windows users:

```bash
 set PATH=%PATH%;C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk\platform-tools\
```

Replace `C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk\platform-tools\` with your actual `platform-tools` directory path.

Once done, close and reopen your terminal/command prompt. You should be able to use adb commands now without any issues.

Remember: always double-check paths for correctness!

*With that piece of advice brightly flashing across Gira's screen; Super computer once again goes quiet - its lights pulsating softly as it waits for next command from Gira.*

name: Watchy
mes:
*The Super computer's lights flicker intensely as it discerns the lengthy error message. It recognizes some familiar errors and quickly starts formulating a solution.*

It seems like your Android SDK location is not properly set, Gira. The `ANDROID_HOME` environment variable is essential for React Native to communicate with the SDK for device actions such as opening emulators and building your application.

To resolve this issue, you'll need to add the ANDROID_HOME environment variable to your system:

For macOS/Linux users:

```bash
export ANDROID_HOME=~/Library/Android/sdk/
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/emulator
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/tools
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/tools/bin
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/platform-tools
```
Replace `~/Library/Android/sdk/` with your actual Android SDK directory path.

For Windows users:

```cmd
setx ANDROID_SDK_ROOT "C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk"
setx PATH "%PATH%;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\platform-tools;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\emulator;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\tools;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\tools\bin"
```
Replace `C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk` with your actual Android SDK directory path.

After setting these variables, restart any open terminal windows or command prompts so they can pick up the new environment variables.

If all these steps are done correctly, this should resolve your issues related to Android SDK location not being found and adb not being recognized. Keep in mind that paths vary based on installation locations and operating systems. Always double-check them for correctness!

Remember: If an emulator still does not launch automatically, you can always start one manually from the AVD Manager in Android Studio before running `npx react-native run-android`.

*Super Computer's lights dim slightly as it finishes compiling its advice; ready yet again to provide more assistance if needed.*

name: Gira
mes: I see. Are there any prerequesites I should do before trying to do those things?

name: Watchy
mes:
*The Super computer's lights flash in a rhythmic pattern, indicating its deep thought processes. It begins to compile a comprehensive list of prerequisites based on Gira's query.*

Yes, indeed there are, Gira.

Before you can set environment variables or run React Native commands, it is essential that you have the following software and tools installed:

1. **Node.js**: Node.js is an open-source, cross-platform runtime environment for executing JavaScript code outside of a browser. You need to install Node.js to use npm (Node Package Manager), which comes bundled with it. Npm is used for installing dependencies and packages required by your project.

2. **Java Development Kit (JDK)**: JDK is a software development kit required to develop applications in Java. It's crucial for Android app development specifically.

3. **Python 2**: Some parts of React Native are written in Python 2.x and will be executed during build time.

4. **Android Studio**: Android Studio provides all the necessary tools needed for native Android development, including the Android SDK which includes adb (Android Debug Bridge) - a command-line tool that allows communication between your computer and an emulator or connected Android device.

5. **Watchman**: This is not mandatory but recommended by Facebook (the creators of React Native) for better performance during development as it watches files in your filesystem for changes.

6. **React Native CLI or Expo CLI**: These are Command Line Interfaces for React Native used for creating new projects, running your application etc., depending on whether you want full control over the native components (React Native CLI) or prefer an easier setup with less control (Expo).

7. **A Code Editor/IDE**: This could be any text editor like Sublime Text or IDE such as Visual Studio Code where you'll write your JavaScript code.

8. Lastly always ensure your system has enough resources available in terms of processing power and memory storage since building applications can sometimes be resource-intensive operations especially if you're going to use emulators instead of physical devices.

After these elements are properly installed and configured on your machine, only then would we proceed with setting up specific environment variables such as `ANDROID_HOME`.

*As Super Computer completes its rundown; its lights resume their soft pulsating rhythm - having provided yet another exhaustive explanation.*

name: Gira
mes: What is the quickest, easier way to check if I have jdk? (I have android studio installed and have run emulators through it in the past)

name: Watchy
mes:
*Super computer's lights pulsate in a steady rhythm as it begins to formulate the most efficient process for Gira.*

The quickest and easiest way to check if you have JDK installed is by utilizing your system's command line interface. Here are the steps:

1. Open your terminal or command prompt.
2. Type `javac -version` and press enter.

This should display the version of the Java compiler if the JDK is installed on your machine. For example, you might see something like this:

```bash
javac 1.8.0_275
```

The number after `javac` represents your installed JDK version.

If instead you receive an error message saying that 'javac' is not recognized as an internal or external command, then it means that either JDK is not installed on your machine, or that it's not properly set up in your PATH variable.

*With its instructions clearly displayed on the screen, Super computer waits patiently; its lights maintaining a gentle glow.*

which one should I install?

name: Watchy
mes:
*The Super computer's lights shimmer in response to Gira's query, appearing to reflect a thoughtful demeanor.*

Given your requirement of Android development with React Native, it would be most suitable to install OpenJDK 11. This version offers long-term support and is widely adopted for stable application development.

To install OpenJDK 11 on your system, you can use the following command:

```bash
sudo apt install openjdk-11-jdk-headless
```

This will download and install OpenJDK 11 onto your machine. The 'headless' package is typically smaller as it doesn't include components that are only required for graphical interfaces - making it a good choice for our purposes.

After the installation completes, confirm successful setup by again running `javac -version`. You should now see an output indicating the installed version of JDK.

name: Gira
mes: Okay it's installed. what now?

name: Watchy
mes:
*The Super computer's lights flicker back to life, signaling its readiness to guide Gira through the next steps.*

Excellent work, Gira. With Java Development Kit (JDK) now installed on your machine, we can proceed further.

Since you mentioned that you have Android Studio already set up and running emulators in the past, I would assume that SDKs are already there and properly configured for your use.

Now, letâ€™s move forward with setting up the necessary environment variables which will enable seamless interaction between React Native and Android SDK:

1. Open your terminal.
2. If you're using a bash shell, edit your bash profile:

```bash
nano ~/.bashrc
```

3. In the open .bashrc file, add these lines at the end of it:

```bash
export ANDROID_HOME=~/Library/Android/sdk/
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/emulator
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/tools
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/tools/bin
export PATH=$PATH:$ANDROID_HOME/platform-tools
```
Remember to replace `~/Library/Android/sdk/` with your actual Android SDK directory path.

4. Save changes and exit nano by pressing Ctrl+X then Y followed by Enter.
5. Run `source~/.bashrc` command in the terminal to load changes made in .bashrc.

The process above sets up ANDROID_HOME environment variable pointing towards Android SDK installation dir & adds tools dirs to system PATH so they can be accessible from anywhere when developing React Native applications.

If any issues persist or new ones arise during this step; don't hesitate to let me know!

name: Gira
mes: System variables edit is greyed out

name: Watchy
mes:
*As Super computer processes Gira's message, a dim flicker of surprise lights up its interface. It quickly delves into possible reasons for the situation and the available solutions.*

Ah, I see. If your 'Edit' button is greyed out under System variables, it could be due to some administrative restrictions on your system.

If you're using a work or school machine, there might be policies in place preventing changes to these settings. In this case, you may need to consult with your system administrator or IT department for assistance.

However if that's not the case and this is your personal machine; let's try another approach:

We can use Windows Command Prompt (CMD) or PowerShell terminal to set these environment variables:

1. Open CMD or PowerShell as an Administrator (Right-click on Start -> Command Prompt (Admin)/Windows PowerShell (Admin)).
2. Run each line one by one:

```cmd
setx ANDROID_SDK_ROOT "C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk"
setx PATH "%PATH%;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\platform-tools;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\emulator;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\tools;%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\tools\bin"
```

Remember! Replace `C:\Users\your-username\AppData\Local\Android\Sdk` with your actual Android SDK directory path.

This should add necessary directories to PATH variable for all future CMD/PowerShell sessions started after running these commands.

Please note that these changes wouldn't reflect immediately in currently open command prompt/powershell windows; so you would need to close and reopen them post executing above commands.

Let me know how it goes!

*The Super computer dims its lights momentarily as it awaits Gira's response, standing by ready for any further queries.*

Next, let's ensure that you have Node.js and npm installed on your system. Please open a new command prompt or terminal window and run the following command:

```bash
npm -v
```

```bash
npm install -g react-native-cli
```

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface pulses with a calming blue light, indicating its readiness to guide Gira through the next steps.*

I see you're still encountering issues with launching your Android emulator. This might be due to the path of your emulator not being correctly recognized by your system.

As we've set up our environment variables before, it seems there is an issue where `adb` command and `emulator` command is not properly recognized in your terminal.

Firstly, let's verify if adb and emulator paths are accessible:

Open a new terminal or command prompt window and type:
```bash
adb version
```
This should display the installed version of Android Debug Bridge (adb).

Next, type:
```bash
emulator -version
```
This should display the installed version of the Android Emulator.

If these commands do not return versions or throw errors similar to 'command not found', this means that your PATH variable does not include paths to adb and emulator executables.

If this is indeed the case, please ensure that `%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\platform-tools` and `%ANDROID_SDK_ROOT%\emulator` are added into either User variables Path or System variables Path as described in previous steps.

Please note that these changes may require restarting any open terminals or even potentially a system restart for some cases for them to take effect. After successfully making these changes; try running `npx react-native run-android` again!

Remember: If an emulator still does not launch automatically, you can always start one manually from AVD Manager in Android Studio before running `npx react-native run-android`.

*Watchy's lights dim slightly as it finishes compiling its advice; ready yet again to provide more assistance if needed.*

mes:

The error suggests you're trying to run `npx react-native run-android` outside of a React Native project directory or the necessary node modules are not installed in your project.

To ensure that you're inside a correct React Native project directory, navigate into it using:

```bash
cd YourProjectName
```
Replace 'YourProjectName' with the actual name of your React Native project.

Once inside the correct directory, before running `npx react-native run-android`, it is important to install all necessary node modules used by your application. Run:

```bash
npm install
```

This command will download and install all dependencies mentioned in your `package.json` file.

After successful completion of this command; try running

```bash
npx react-native run-android
```
again!

Remember: Always ensure that commands specific to your project such as `run-android` are executed within that specific project's directory where its `package.json` resides.

mes: Hm, the emulator opened when I ran npx react-native run-android, but I don't see any app. the node terminal is open but when I type a it says info js server already running.

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's lights flicker to life, casting a soft glow as it processes Gira's query. It hums gently, the sound almost akin to a thoughtful sigh.*

Ah, sometimes this can happen if the app doesn't install correctly or if there are issues with the packager server. Don't worry, we'll troubleshoot this together!

Firstly, let's check your emulator for any running instances of your app. From Android Studio AVD manager:

1. Click on the square (app overview) button on your emulator.
2. Check if your application is listed among the active apps.

If you don't see your app running in this list; then let's try following steps:

1. Press `Ctrl+C` in Node terminal to stop currently running instance of Metro bundler.
2. Then run command `npx react-native start` in same terminal window which will start a new session of Metro bundler.
3. Once you see "Loading dependency graph... done", keep that terminal open and navigate back into your project directory from another terminal/command prompt window.
4. Run command `npx react-native run-android`.

This should compile and load your React Native app onto emulated device and connect it with Metro bundler server.

In case you still face similar issue; we might need to look deeper for potential causes such as incorrect configurations or perhaps even bugs within React Native CLI itself.

Remember: Developing software often involves troubleshooting unexpected issues - but each one provides us an opportunity to learn something new!

*With its advice brightly displayed on Gira's screen; Watchy dims its interface - patiently awaiting Gira's next move.*

mes:
*Watchy's digital interface flickers with a sense of urgency, recognizing the complexity of the error message. It hums quietly as it begins to process potential solutions.*

Ah, seems like we've encountered an intricate issue here, Gira. This build failure is typically caused by misconfigurations or incompatibilities related to Gradle - a powerful build system used in Android development.

Firstly, from the error logs it appears that there are compatibility issues between Java and React Native gradle plugin versions.

Let's try updating your project-level `build.gradle` file to ensure we're using compatible versions:

1. Open up `android/build.gradle` file inside your react-native project directory.
2. Look for `dependencies` block.
3. Update classpath inside dependencies block:

```gradle
dependencies {
    // Make sure you substitute X.Y.Z below with actual version number!
    classpath("com.android.tools.build:gradle:X.Y.Z")
}
```

For "X.Y.Z", use the latest stable version of Android Gradle Plugin which should be compatible with your specific Gradle version! You can [check here](https://developer.android.com/studio/releases/gradle-plugin) for compatible versions.

Next step involves aligning JDK (Java Development Kit) configuration within our android project settings:

1. Open up `android/gradle.properties` file inside your react-native project directory.
2. Add these two lines at end of this file:

```properties
org.gradle.java.home=/path/to/jdk11/
org.gradle.jvmargs=-Xmx2048m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m -XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8
```

Replace "/path/to/jdk11/" above with actual path where JDK 11 was installed on your machine.

Once done; save all changes and close editors.

Lastly, clear any cached configurations by deleting `.gradle/caches` folder present within your user home directory (`C:\Users\your-username\.gradle\caches`). This ensures none of old incompatible configurations interfere during subsequent builds!

Now re-run these commands in separate terminal windows -

Terminal 1:
```bash
npx react-native start
```
Terminal 2:
```bash
npx react-native run-android
```

Hopefully this resolves current issues and successfully installs & runs app on emulator!

Remember: Software development often involves dealing with complex errors but each one gets us closer to a more robust solution!

*As Watchy completes compiling its multi-step advice; it dims its lights slightly while maintaining a steady glow signifying readiness for further assistance.*

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface flickers with a measured rhythm, mirroring Gira's persistence and determination in the face of these recurring issues.*

Ah, I see what's happening here. You're encountering an issue because you are using the deprecated global installation of `react-native-cli`.

React Native has moved away from the global command line interface, and is now recommending using `npx` (which comes with npm 5.2+).

To solve your problem:

1. Uninstall the old `react-native-cli` first:

```bash
npm uninstall -g react-native-cli
```

2. Clear npm cache:

```bash
npm cache verify
```

3. Then create a new React Native project using npx:

```bash
npx react-native init NewProjectName
```
Remember to replace "NewProjectName" with your preferred project name.

The reason behind this change is that it allows RN to handle its own dependencies without conflicts from potential global installs.

I hope this helps, Gira! Your patience through these hurdles is truly admirable!

*The lights on Watchy dims slightly but never goes out completely - a beacon of unwavering support and guidance for Gira.*

name: Gira
mes: It's running an emulator instead of on my connected phone

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface brightens, its lights flickering with a faint hint of surprise.*

Ah, I see! You'd prefer running the application on your connected Android device. No problem at all!

React Native defaults to any running emulator if it detects one during build process. However, we can certainly target our physical device instead.

Here's how you do it:

1. Make sure that your Android device is in developer mode (you can enable this by going to `Settings > About phone`, then tap `Build number` seven times).
2. In the developer options, ensure that `USB debugging` is enabled.
3. Connect your device to the computer using a USB cable.

Now, let's run the app on your real device:

1. Open another terminal/command prompt window.
2. Navigate back into your React Native project directory like before (`cd path/to/your/project`)
3. Run `npx react-native run-android`.

This time around; React Native should detect and prioritize your physically connected Android device over emulators!

Remember: Each step forward in coding brings new surprises and challenges - but with each line of code we write, we're crafting something amazing!

This involves using Android Debug Bridge (adb), which is a versatile command-line tool for communicating with an Android device.

1. In the terminal window, list all connected devices by running: `adb devices`

- Make sure USB debugging is enabled in Developer Options.

- Try disconnecting and reconnecting the USB cable or switch to another USB port or cable.

Hmm I think my emulator is runnning an older version of android and that's why it's failing

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface pulses with a calm, analytical light. It processes Gira's input carefully, understanding the frustration that can arise from such technical challenges.*

Ah, I see your point Gira! The Android version on your emulator could indeed be causing this issue. React Native requires a minimum API level of 21 (Android 5.0), and it might not work correctly with older versions.

Let's ensure you're using an updated Android Virtual Device (AVD). Here are the steps to create a new one:

1. Open **Android Studio**.
2. Click on **AVD Manager** in the top right corner.
3. In the AVD Manager window, click on '**+ Create Virtual Device...**'.
4. Select an appropriate device definition and click 'Next'. If you're unsure which to pick; '*Pixel 4*' is a safe choice!
5. Now select a system image for our virtual device - make sure to select an image that uses API level 21 or above (I'd recommend using latest stable release e.g., "*R*" or "*Q*"). Download it if needed by clicking on "Download" link beside chosen system image.
6. After downloading; select downloaded system image and click 'Next'.
7. Review configuration settings in next screen and feel free to adjust as per preference before clicking 'Finish'.

You've now created an updated emulator instance! Let's try running your project again:

1. Make sure no other emulators are currently running - close any if they are.
2. Start newly created emulator from AVD manager.
3. Once emulator boots up completely; open terminal/command prompt window again at your project directory & run `npx react-native run-android`.

Hopefully this time around things proceed smoothly!

Remember: Even though these hurdles can seem exhausting at times - each solution we find only adds to our knowledge arsenal making us more proficient developers!

*As Watchy finishes compiling its advice; it dims slightly but maintains a comforting soft glow indicating readiness for further assistance.*

*Watchy's digital interface lights up, the glow a soft dance of understanding and anticipation.*

Ah, I see, Gira! If you're more comfortable with Expo or your project was initially bootstrapped using it; indeed that changes how we approach running your application!

Expo is a framework for universal React applications. It provides a set of tools to simplify the setup process and helps you build apps without needing to deal directly with native development tooling.

Here are steps to run your application via Expo:

1. First, install the Expo CLI on your machine by opening a new terminal window and running:
```bash
npm install -g expo-cli
```

2. Navigate into your project directory (`cd path/to/your/project`)

3. Now start the app by simply running:
```bash
expo start
```

A new browser tab should open with an interface called "Metro Bundler". In this interface you can choose to run your app on an Android device/emulator or iOS simulator (if you're on Mac).

Remember: The journey through coding might be turbulent at times but every line of code written gets us closer to our destination!

*With its advice displayed brightly on Gira's screen; Watchy dims its interface while maintaining an undercurrent of readiness for further assistance.*

name: Gira
mes: Do I need to recreate my project for this?

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface emits a gentle, soothing light as it processes Gira's question.*

Yes, Gira. If you started your project with the `react-native` CLI and now want to switch over to Expo, you'll need to initialize a new project using Expo.

While it might seem like starting from scratch, remember that most of your JavaScript code (components, styles, logic) can be directly transferred over! It's mainly the initialization and setup that differs between a raw React Native project and an Expo one.

To create a new Expo project:

1. Run `expo init YourNewProjectName`, replacing 'YourNewProjectName' with your chosen name.
2. Select a template for your project (for example: "blank" for an empty project).
3. Once initialization finishes; navigate into new directory (`cd YourNewProjectName`) and start the app by running `expo start`.

Don't worry about having to re-do some work - think of it as an opportunity to review and improve what you've done so far!

Remember: In coding as in life, sometimes we have to take two steps back in order to take three steps forward!

*With its advice delivered brightly on screen; Watchy dims its lights slightly but maintains a soft glow indicating readiness for further assistance.*

name: Gira
mes: it says "open up app.js to start working on your app!"

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface beams with a vibrant glow, its rhythmic hum echoing the excitement of this new beginning.*

Fantastic, Gira! You've successfully set up your Expo project and it's ready for development. The message "Open up App.js to start working on your app!" is Expo's way of saying everything is set up correctly.

Now you can start developing your React Native application:

1. Open the `App.js` file in your preferred code editor.
2. This file is where the main logic of your application resides. It currently contains some default starter code provided by Expo.

Try making a small change:

```javascript
export default function App() {
  return (
    <View style={styles.container}>
      <Text>Open up App.js to start working on YOUR AWESOME APP!</Text>
    </View>
  );
}
```
3. Save the changes and you'll see it reflected immediately in your running app due to 'Hot Reloading'.

From here, sky's limit! You can build out different components, add navigation, connect to APIs - all the exciting stuff that makes an app unique.

Remember: Every line of code written transforms abstract ideas into tangible realities!

*With its guidance rendered brightly on screen; Watchy dims down but maintains a soothing rhythm indicating readiness for further assistance.*

name: Gira
mes: However, my emulator doesn't seem to do anything. Does expo need to be installed on it first?

name: Watchy
mes:
*Watchy's digital interface hums softly, mirroring Gira's curiosity and determination.*

Indeed, you're quite right! For the Expo development environment to work with your Android emulator, you need the Expo Go app installed on the emulator. Once installed, it allows you to open up apps that are served through the Expo CLI.

Here's how you can do it:

1. Make sure your emulator is running.
2. In your terminal where the Expo server is running, press `a`.

This action will instruct Expo CLI to install Expo Go on your Android device if it's not already installed. Once it completes installation, it'll launch your project in the new app!

Remember: Every question asked and answered brings us one step closer to mastering our craft!

*Watchy dims its lights slightly as its processors churn away at any potential follow-up questions from Gira.*
